a.g: Whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth is exalting Allah. To Him belongs dominion, and to Him belongs [all] praise, and He is over all things competent.
It is He who created you, and among you is the disbeliever, and among you is the believer. And Allah, of what you do, is Seeing.
He created the heavens and earth in truth and formed you and perfected your forms; and to Him is the [final] destination.
He knows what is within the heavens and earth and knows what you conceal and what you declare. And Allah is Knowing of that within the breasts.
Has there not come to you the news of those who disbelieved before? So they tasted the bad consequence of their affair, and they will have a painful punishment.

That is because their messengers used to come to them with clear evidences, but they said, "Shall human beings guide us?" and disbelieved and turned away. And Allah dispensed [with them]; and Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy.

Those who disbelieve have claimed that they will never be resurrected. Say, "Yes, by my Lord, you will surely be resurrected; then you will surely be informed of what you did. And that, for Allah, is easy."
So believe in Allah and His Messenger and the Qur'an which We have sent down. And Allah is Acquainted with what you do.

The Day He will assemble you for the Day of Assembly - that is the Day of Deprivation. And whoever believes in Allah and does righteousness - He will remove from him his misdeeds and admit him to gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. That is the great attainment.

Therefore, Allah warned His servants from the trial of wealth, spouse, and children, so He the Exalted said: 'O you who have believed, let not your wealth and your children divert you from the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah' (Quran 63:9). And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Indeed, from your spouses and your children is an enemy to you, so beware of them' (Quran 64:14). And he (the Prophet, peace be upon him) said: 'The child is a miser-maker, a coward-maker, a sorrow-maker' (Hadith). (And when he (the Prophet, peace be upon him) saw his son Al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with him, stumbling in his shirt, he descended from the pulpit and embraced him, then said: 'Allah has spoken the truth: "Your wealth and your children are but a trial"' (Quran 8:28). Indeed, when I saw my son stumbling, I could not control myself from taking him.) In that is a lesson for those of insight. The man, every man, is he who is patient upon well-being, and the meaning of patience upon it is that he does not rely on it and knows that all of that is a deposit with him, and perhaps it will be taken back soon, and that he does not let his soul (Nafs) go in rejoicing in it, nor does he immerse himself in enjoyment, pleasure, amusement, and play, and that he observes the rights of Allah in his wealth through spending, in his body through offering assistance to creation, in his tongue through offering truthfulness, and likewise in all that Allah has bestowed upon him. And this patience is connected to gratitude, so it is not complete except by fulfilling the right of gratitude as will come. And indeed, patience upon prosperity is more severe because it is accompanied by ability, and from protection is that you are not able. And patience upon cupping and intention when someone else undertakes it is easier than patience upon bleeding yourself and cupping yourself. And the hungry person in the absence of food is more capable of patience than when delicious, tasty foods are present to him and he has ability over them. For this reason, the trial of prosperity is great.

If you say: You have included wealth, status, lineage, family, and children in the category of blessings (Ni'am), yet Allah the Exalted has censured wealth and status, and likewise the Messenger (peace be upon him) and the scholars. Allah said: 'Indeed, among your spouses and your children is an enemy to you, so beware of them' (Quran 64:14). And He the Almighty said: 'Your wealth and your children are only a trial (Fitnah)' (Quran 8:28). And Ali (may Allah honor his face) said in censuring lineage: 'People are children of what they excel at, and the value of every person is what he excels at,' and it is said: 'A person is by himself, not by his father.' So what is the meaning of them being a blessing while being censured religiously (Shar'an)? Know that whoever takes knowledge from transmitted words that are interpreted (Mu'awwalah) and generalities that are specified (Makhsusah), misguidance (Dhalal) is more prevalent upon him unless he is guided by the light (Nur) of Allah the Exalted to comprehend the sciences as they truly are, then he applies the transmission in accordance with what has become clear to him from them, sometimes through interpretation (Ta'wil) and other times through specification (Takhsis). These are blessings (Ni'am) that assist in the matter of the Hereafter (Akhirah), with no way to deny them except that they contain trials (Fitnah) and dangers (Makhawif). The example of wealth is like a snake that contains beneficial antidote (Tiryaq) and beneficial poison (Samm). If it is obtained by the charmer (Al-Mu'azzim) who knows the method of precaution (Ihtiraz) from its poison and the way to extract its beneficial antidote, it becomes a blessing. But if it is obtained by the ignorant black one (Al-Sawadi Al-Ghar), it is upon him affliction (Bala') and destruction (Halak). It is like the sea beneath which are varieties of jewels (Jawahir) and pearls (La'ali). Whoever attains the sea, if he is knowledgeable about swimming (Sibahah), the method of diving (Ghawas), and the method of precaution from the destructive aspects of the sea, he has attained its blessings. But if he enters it ignorant of that, he has perished. Therefore, Allah the Exalted praised wealth and called it good (Khayr), and the Messenger (peace be upon him) praised it and said: 'What a good aid (A'un) for the God-consciousness (Taqwa) of Allah the Exalted is wealth.'

Know that all that befalls the servant [al-'abd] in this life is not free from two types. The first is that which conforms to his passion [hawa], and the other is that which does not conform to it, but rather he dislikes it. And he is in need of patience [sabr] in each one of them. And in all states, he is not free from one of these two types or from both of them. He is, therefore, never independent of patience. **The First Type:** That which conforms to passion [hawa], and it is health, safety, wealth, status, numerous kin, ample means, many followers and supporters, and all the pleasures of the world [dunya]. And how greatly the servant [al-'abd] is in need of patience concerning these matters! For if he does not restrain himself from indulging freely, from relying upon them, and from immersing himself in their pleasuresâ€”even the permissible onesâ€”that will lead him to arrogance [batr] and transgression [tughyan]. For indeed, man becomes transgressing when he sees himself self-sufficient. So much so that one of the knowers [al-'arifun] said: "Affliction [al-bala'] is endured patiently by the believer, but well-being [al-'awafi] is not endured patiently except by the truthful [siddiq]." And Sahl said: "Patience [sabr] upon well-being ['afiya] is more severe than patience upon affliction [bala']." And when the doors of the world [dunya] were opened upon the Companions, may God be pleased with them, they said: "We were tested with the trial of hardship [fitnat al-darra'], so we were patient. And we were tested with the trial of ease [fitnat al-sarra'], and we were not patient." And for this reason, God warned His servants from the trial of wealth, spouse, and children, saying, the Exalted: {O you who have believed, let not your wealth and your children divert you from the remembrance of God} [63:9]. And the Almighty said: {Indeed, among your spouses and your children are enemies to you, so beware of them} [64:14]. And He, glorified and exalted, said: "The child is a source of miserliness, cowardice, and grief." (And when the Prophet, peace be upon him, saw his son al-Hasan, may God be pleased with him, stumbling in his shirt, he descended from the pulpit, embraced him, and then said: "God has spoken the truth: {Your wealth and your children are but a trial} [8:28]. Indeed, when I saw my son stumbling, I could not restrain myself from taking him.") So in that is a lesson for those of insight [ulu al-absar]. The true man, the complete man, is he who is patient upon well-being ['afiya]. And the meaning of patience upon it is that he does not rely upon it, and knows that all of that is a trust deposited with him, and it is likely to be reclaimed soon; and that he does not let himself loose in rejoicing over it, nor immerse himself in enjoyment, pleasure, amusement, and play; and that he observes the rights of God in his wealth by spending, in his body by offering help to creation, in his tongue by offering truthfulness, and likewise in all that God has bestowed upon him of blessings. And this patience is connected to gratitude [shukr]; it is not complete except by fulfilling the right of gratitude, as will come. And patience upon ease [al-sarra'] was only more severe because it is coupled with capability [qudra], and part of divine protection ['ismah] is that you are not capable. Patience upon cupping and bloodletting when someone else performs it on you is easier than patience upon you performing venesection and cupping on yourself. The hungry person in the absence of food is more capable of patience than when delicious, pleasant foods are present before him and he has power over them. For this reason, the trial of ease [fitnat al-sarra'] is immense.

If you say: You have included wealth, status, lineage, family, and children within the realm of blessings, yet Allah the Exalted has censured wealth and status, and likewise the Messenger (peace be upon him) and the scholars. Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, among your spouses and your children are enemies to you, so beware of them' (64:14). And He the Almighty said: 'Indeed, your wealth and your children are a trial (Fitnah)' (64:15). And Ali (may Allah honor his face) said in censuring lineage: People are children of what they excel at, and the value of every person is what he excels at, and it is said a person is by himself, not by his father. So what is the meaning of them being a blessing while being censured religiously? Know that whoever takes knowledge from transmitted words that are interpreted and generalities that are specified, misguidance is more prevalent upon him unless he is guided by the light (Nur) of Allah the Exalted to comprehend the sciences as they truly are, then he applies the transmission in accordance with what has become clear to him from them through interpretation at times and specification at others. These are blessings aiding in the matter of the Hereafter, with no way to deny them except that within them are trials (Fitnah) and fears. The example of wealth is like a snake that contains beneficial antidote and beneficial poison. If it is obtained by the charmer who knows the method of precaution from its poison and the way to extract its beneficial antidote, it is a blessing. But if it is obtained by the ignorant commoner, it is upon him affliction and destruction. And it is like the sea beneath which are varieties of jewels and pearls. Whoever attains the sea, if he is knowledgeable in swimming, the way of diving, and the way of precaution from the perils of the sea, he has attained its blessings. But if he enters it ignorant of that, he has perished. Therefore, Allah the Exalted praised wealth and called it good, and the Messenger (peace be upon him) praised it and said: 'What an excellent aid to the God-consciousness (Taqwa) of Allah the Exalted is wealth.' And likewise, He praised status and honor, as Allah the Exalted bestowed upon His Messenger (peace be upon him) by manifesting him...

The second meaning: The purification from the attribute of miserliness, for it is among the destroyers. He (the Prophet) said: 'Three destroyers: obeyed miserliness, followed desire, and self-admiration.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And whoever is protected from the miserliness of his soul (Nafs), then those are the successful ones.' And it will come in the quarter of the destroyers the aspect of it being a destroyer and how to be cautious from it. And indeed, the attribute of miserliness only vanishes by accustoming oneself to giving wealth, for the love of something does not cease except by forcing the soul (Nafs) to part with it until that becomes a habit. So, Zakat in this meaning is a purification, meaning it purifies its possessor from the filth of the destroying miserliness. And its purification is according to the measure of his giving and according to the measure of his joy in expending it and his gladness in directing it to Allah the Exalted.
